title: Beirut is caught in the crossfire, its inhabitants split between apathy and solidarity with refugees
summary: The war has hit a city at the end of its tether, still reeling from the 2019 financial crisis and the devastating port explosion the following year, but thousands have flocked there from the south, fleeing bombings.

title: Israel steps up attacks against the United Nations
summary: Benjamin Netanyahu's government is increasingly attacking UNIFIL and UNRWA, the Palestinian refugee agency. UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres has been declared persona non grata on Israeli soil.

title: Villas, luxury cars worth €70 million and belonging to Russian oligarchs seized in France
summary: The Paris prosecutor's office has obtained the seizure of these assets in an aggravated money laundering investigation, illustrating a new doctrine that reverses the burden of proof in opaque financial arrangements.

title: Uproar over sale of beloved French painkiller to American company
summary: Politicians and groups from all sides have said the sale of the popular Doliprane drug would be a 'loss of sovereignty'.

title: China encircles Taiwan in heightened military drills
summary: The Chinese army deployed fighter jets, bombers and warships to encircle the island.

title: Le Pen claims innocence in fake EU jobs trial
summary: French far-right leader Marine Le Pen strongly denied committing any wrongdoing at a Paris court Monday as she and her Rassemblement National party stand trial over the suspected embezzlement of European Parliament funds.

title: Madrid's youth rises against soaring housing cost
summary: In the Spanish capital, rental prices have risen by an average of almost 30% over the last five years.

title: Russia sentences French researcher to three years in a penal colony
summary: Laurent Vinatier, who works for a Swiss NGO, is accused of gathering information on Russia's military without being registered as a 'foreign agent'.

title: Nobel economics prize awarded for research into differences in prosperity between nations
summary: Three researchers at American universities were awarded the Nobel memorial prize in economics for their research into why some societies are wealthier than others.

title: The scourge of gang rape is nothing new
summary: A number of high-profile attacks have left their mark on public opinion, with victims now speaking out.

title: Canada and India expel six of each other's diplomats
summary: Tensions between the two nations have escalated since Canada alleged that the Indian government was linked to the June 2023 assassination of Sikh activist Hardeep Singh Nijjar.

title: Alexei Navalny's 'Patriot,' the unfinished memoir of Putin's leading opponent
summary: In a book to be published on October 22 in France, Navalny recounts his childhood, the roots of his activism and his harrowing experience in Kharp prison in the Arctic, where he died in February.

title: NASA probe lifts off to discover whether Jupiter's icy moon has life
summary: The Europa Clipper launched Monday to explore Jupiter's moon Europa and investigate whether its hidden ocean could support life. It will take 5.5 years to reach Jupiter, where it will orbit the planet and conduct multiple flybys.

title: French government wants new immigration bill in 2025, less than a year after the last one
summary: Government spokeswoman Maud Bregeon confirmed the bill will include measures 'useful for protecting the French.'

title: Increase in loggerhead turtle nests found on French beaches
summary: Found mainly in Greece and Turkey, these turtles – a protected species – have been laying eggs on France's Mediterranean coast for the past two years.

title: US presidential election: A Trump victory could influence the International Energy Agency
summary: If the Republican candidate were to return to the White House, the organization focused on decarbonizing the sector would be targeted by the new administration.

title: The anguish of Lebanese artists invited to France for the Festival d'Automne
summary: The current conflict in the Middle East has had a major impact on the work of Lebanese directors Lina Majdalanie and Rabih Mroué, whose work is on show at the Paris Fall Festival.

title: One year after a terrorist murdered a teacher, an entire community's trauma persists
summary: A tribute was paid to murdered literature teacher Dominique Bernard on Friday, at the school in northern France where he was killed. A public ceremony is being organized on Sunday, with Isabelle Bernard, the teacher's widow.

title: First signs of a post-Nasrallah political era emerge in Lebanon
summary: For the Christian Right, the death of Hezbollah's leader brings hopes for a rebalancing of power.

title: Taiwan detects record-breaking 153 Chinese military aircraft during drills
summary: Japan says it has told China about its 'concerns', adding that it scrambled fighter jets near its southern island of Yonaguni.

title: Poland's plan to curb asylum rights draws criticism and controversy
summary: While Prime Minister Donald Tusk warned on Saturday that he would not implement a European obligation that would contravene the country's 'security,' the European Commission warned that Warsaw must provide asylum seekers with 'access to a protection procedure.'

title: European Union will propose new law to increase deportations
summary: In a letter, the head of the European Commission tole member states it needs to facilitate and harmonize the deportation of irregular migrants.

title: US presidential election: 'Even if Kamala Harris wins, the Supreme Court's move to the right will continue'
summary: Legal expert Anne Deysine highlights a hidden political issue in the November presidential election: the balance of power on the Supreme Court, where the radical right is in a strong position.

title: $7 billion takeover revives lithium battle
summary: Mining group Rio Tinto has acquired Arcadium Lithium, one of the world leaders in the extraction of that essential mineral for the production of electric batteries. The $6.7 billion deal comes at a time when the white gold market is in decline.

title: Militia threat in North Carolina force hurricane relief teams to change help tactics
summary: FEMA, the Federal Emergency Management Agency, has faced targeted disinformation in its response to Hurricane Helene.

title: Nobel Prize 2024: When economics meets history
summary: Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson and James Robinson have been awarded the Bank of Sweden Prize in Economic Sciences for their work on global wealth inequality.

title: North Korea blows up sections of roads connecting it to the South
summary: Pyongyang's military last week vowed to permanently seal its southern border. Seoul said it conducted a 'counter-fire' operation in response.

title: Several EU countries now question welcoming conditions for Ukrainian refugees
summary: Norway, Hungary and the Czech Republic have imposed restrictions on the entry or social rights of those fleeing the Russian invasion. They have raised concerns about the burden of supporting refugees and the presence of men of military age.

title: Paul Pogba hungry to return to football after doping ban
summary: Pogba, who is under contract with Italian giants Juventus, will be able to return to football from March 11 of next year, after his doping ban was reduced to 18 months.

title: 'I don't feel I've committed the slightest irregularity,' Le Pen tells court at party's fake jobs trial
summary: The former president of the Rassemblement National and former Member of the European Parliament is facing charges of 'misappropriation of public funds.' She is appearing before the Paris Criminal Court from Monday, October 14 to Wednesday, October 16.

title: China steps up pressure on Taiwan as military drills prepare for potential invasion
summary: The government of the island, which Beijing considers one of its provinces, announced on Tuesday that it had detected a record 153 Chinese aircraft in one day near its territory.

title: Former Stasi lieutenant convicted in Germany for 'mercilessly executing' a 38-year-old Pole
summary: Martin Naumann was sentenced to 10 years in prison for shooting Czeslaw Kukuczka, a 38-year-old father, in the back in 1974 as he tried to cross into West Berlin.

title: Mbappé investigated for rape according to Swedish newspaper, football star says 'fake news'
summary: After newspaper 'Aftonbladet' reported that an alleged rape had been reported to police in Stockholm, 'Expressen' newspaper wrote that French footballer Mbappé was the suspect.

title: One year after October 7, another war wages on in the West Bank
summary: Photographer Sakir Khader has made several trips to the West Bank since the war in Gaza started. Through his work, he seeks to show the daily lives of the inhabitants, especially children, in an environment where violence is omnipresent.

title: After 100 days of Labour government, where's the hope?
summary: A series of missteps has dented British Prime Minister Keir Starmer's political capital, and he is about to present a likely 'painful' budget.

title: Italy sends first group of asylum seekers to Albania
summary: The migrants rescued in the Mediterranean by an Italian ship are scheduled to be disembarked in Albania on Wednesday. However, the legal and logistical viability of this project, proposed by Giorgia Meloni, remains uncertain.

title: Mbappé named in rape investigation after Stockholm party, Swedish media report
summary: On Tuesday, the prosecutor's office confirmed that the police had registered a rape complaint, without naming anyone.

title: 'L'Histoire de Souleymane' wasn't meant to be a 'politically correct film,' director says
summary: Boris Lojkine, who holds a degree in philosophy, sought to shake up the codes of French cinema, both in the stories he tells and in the way he works.

title: 'L'Histoire de Souleymane': Two days of pure suspense in the life of a migrant
summary: Boris Lojkine's film follows an undocumented migrant from Guinea, brilliantly played by Abou Sangare, waiting for his legal status to be granted in France.

title: Macron says Netanyahu 'mustn't forget his country was created by a UN decision'
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's comments about the Israeli prime minister were quoted from a closed-door meeting at the Elysée Palace.

title: 'The US presidential campaign resembles an unfunded quest for a lost paradise'
summary: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are proposing increased spending as if deficits didn't matter. Despite the US not being at war or in recession, the federal government is borrowing heavily, writes Le Monde columnist Stéphane Lauer.

title: Italy's Meloni to visit Lebanon Friday after hits on UN peacekeepers
summary: Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni would be the first head of state or government to visit Lebanon since escalations between Israel and Lebanese militant group Hezbollah in September.

title: Paris' Musée du Quai Branly reveals the legend of the Haitian undead
summary: The Parisian museum devotes a rich exhibition to the history of zombification practices on the Caribbean island with 'Zombies: Death is not the end?'

title: UK announces new sanctions against Israeli settlers
summary: The sanctions against the Israeli settlers are the third imposed by London targeting those involved in settler violence since February.

title: Ubisoft staff in France strike over home working
summary: The strike was sparked by a September message from management insisting on a return to three days working in the office for all staff worldwide.

title: Mbappé's lawyer says footballer to take legal action for libel over rape claims
summary: According to Swedish media, an investigation has been opened against the player for rape and sexual assault in Stockholm.

title: US warns Israel that aid could be withheld
summary: The letter, weeks before a US election, comes a year into the Israel-Hamas war in which President Joe Biden has repeatedly voiced concern about the lack of assistance and high civilian casualties but only once is known to have blocked a shipment in the billions of dollars of US aid to Israel.

title: North Korea blows up roads, rails to South
summary: South Korea's military released video footage showing North Korean soldiers in military uniforms ahead of a huge explosion, which emitted thick billowing smoke as it blew up sections of the Gyeongui road.
